We say that an infinite simple group G is a monster of the third kind if for every non-trivial elements a, b, of which at least one is not an involution, there are infinitely many elements g ∈ G such that ⟨a, bg⟩ = G. (Compare with V. P. Shunkov’s definitions in Archive, 6.63, 6.64.) Is it true that every simple quasi-Chernikov group is a monster of the third kind? This is true for quasi-finite groups (A. I. Sozutov, Algebra and Logic, 36, no. 5 (1997), 336–348). (We say that a non-σ group is quasi-σ if all of its proper subgroups have the property σ.)
A. I. Sozutov
